subject: Politics
title: How Laws Are Made
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on How Laws Are Made.

hook.text: A bill becomes a law through debate, amendment, and voting. In reality, most bills die in committee.

buildup.text: Legislation starts as a proposal. It moves through committees, debates, votes, and executive approval.

discovery.text: In the US Congress, fewer than 5% of bills become law. The process filters out most ideas.

twist.text: Lobbying shapes what passes. Industries spend billions to make sure laws serve their interests.

climax.text: Law-making is messy, slow, and political. That slowness partly prevents rash, harmful action.

punchline.text: Making laws is slow on purpose. Speed favors whoever has power.

quiz.question: What percentage of bills introduced to the US Congress become law?
